article_text:
Sachiko Kuno and Ryuji Uenoown two of the largest historic houses in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, but they live in neither. Instead, they use them to host concerts, parties, debates—and earlier this year, an Easter Egg Roll.

The Japanese-born couple decided to buy the Federal-style Evermay Estate in 2011 as a base for their philanthropic work, the S&R Foundation, a nonprofit that supports individuals in the arts and sciences. Its cascading terraces, with a sweeping view of downtown D.C., are great for...

article_summary:
Sachiko Kuno and Ryuji Uenoown two of the largest historic houses in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, but they live in neither.
Its cascading terraces, with a sweeping view of downtown D.C., are great for...
Instead, they use them to host concerts, parties, debates—and earlier this year, an Easter Egg Roll.
The Japanese-born couple decided to buy the Federal-style Evermay Estate in 2011 as a base for their philanthropic work, the S&R Foundation, a nonprofit that supports individuals in the arts and sciences.
